message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and history suggest pubic lice, which are caused by Phthirus pubis. Pediculus humanus can cause body lice, but not in the area of genitals. Enterobius vermicularis causes pinworms, and Epidermophyton floccosum causes fungal infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and photomicrograph suggest the most likely causal organism is Phthirus pubis, also known as pubic lice or crab lice. Pediculus humanus is the head louse or body louse. Enterobius vermicularis is the pinworm. Epidermophyton floccosum is a fungus that causes tinea cruris or jock itch, but the symptoms do not match the patient's description.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest pubic lice, which are caused by Phthirus pubis. The photomicrograph shows the characteristic crab-like shape of pubic lice. Pediculus humanus causes body lice, not pubic lice. Enterobius vermicularis causes pinworm infection, which does not typically affect the genital area. Epidermophyton floccosum causes tinea cruris or "jock itch," which can affect the genital area but does not typically present with severe itching at night.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and sexual history suggest the most likely cause is Phthirus pubis, also known as pubic lice. The photomicrograph provided is also consistent with this diagnosis as pubic lice have distinctive claw-like legs that are visible under a microscope. Pediculus humanus is also a louse but is typically found on the scalp or body, not in the pubic area. Enterobius vermicularis is a type of intestinal worm that can cause anal itching but is not associated with the symptoms described. Epidermophyton floccosum is a type of fungus that can cause ringworm but does not typically manifest with the symptoms described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the severe itching at night, suggest pubic lice (Phthirus pubis) as the most likely causal organism, which is also supported by the photomicrograph of an epilated pubic hair. Pediculus humanus and Enterobius vermicularis do not cause genital itching, and Epidermophyton floccosum causes fungal infection of the skin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially severe itching at night, suggest the most likely causal organism is Phthirus pubis (also known as pubic lice). The photograph of the pubic hair can show the lice or their eggs. Pediculus humanus (body lice) can also cause severe itching but is generally associated with poorer hygiene. Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm) is a parasitic infection that can cause perianal itching, but is not typically associated with sexual activity. Epidermophyton floccosum is a dermatophyte that can cause fungal infections such as tinea cruris (jock itch), but is not known to cause severe itching at night.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and sexual history suggest a pubic lice infestation, which is caused by the organism Phthirus pubis. The photomicrograph of an epilated pubic hair can also aid in the diagnosis, as pubic lice and their eggs will be visible. Pediculus humanus and Enterobius vermicularis are parasites that can cause itching and irritation, but they do not commonly infest the pubic region. Epidermophyton floccosum is a fungal infection that can cause itching and skin irritation, but it is not associated with pubic lice infestation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptom of severe itching in the genital area, especially at night, and the presence of vulvar excoriations suggest that the patient might have pubic lice, which is caused by Phthirus pubis. The fact that her current sexual partner is experiencing similar symptoms supports this diagnosis. Pediculus humanus is the cause of body lice, and Enterobius vermicularis is the cause of pinworm infection. Epidermophyton floccosum causes a fungal infection of the skin, which is not consistent with the symptoms. The photomicrograph is not provided in the question stem.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The photomicrograph shows the characteristic "crab-like" appearance of Phthirus pubis, also known as pubic lice. The symptoms and sexual activity also support this diagnosis. Pediculus humanus (body lice) and Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm) are not associated with itching in the genital area, and Epidermophyton floccosum causes skin infections like ringworm, but not itching in this location.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of severe itching in the area of the genitals, most severe at night, and vulvar excoriations suggest the most likely causal organism is Phthirus pubis, also known as pubic lice. Pediculus humanus is the body louse, not typically found in the pubic area. Enterobius vermicularis is the pinworm, which does not typically cause genital itching. Epidermophyton floccosum is a fungus that can cause tinea cruris or "jock itch," but typically does not cause itching in the area of the genitals. The photomicrograph of an epilated pubic hair can confirm the diagnosis of pubic lice, which can be treated with topical insecticides.
